name: Mountain Pose
precaution: If you have any lower back or neck issues, be sure to keep your spine in alignment by gently engaging your core muscles to prevent overarching. Avoid locking your knees, and instead, keep them slightly soft to prevent hyperextension. As with any yoga pose, listen to your body, and if you experience discomfort or pain, ease out of the pose and consult a healthcare provider if needed.

name: Downward-Facing Dog
precaution: Individuals with wrist issues should avoid excessive weight on the wrists, ensuring the fingers are spread wide and the weight is distributed evenly across the palms. For those with shoulder concerns, the shoulders should be engaged by pressing the shoulder blades down the back to prevent any unnecessary strain. The neck should remain in a neutral position, with the gaze directed between the legs or at the belly button. Avoid dropping or craning the neck, as this can cause tension in the cervical spine. Pregnant individuals should avoid Downward Dog, particularly after the first trimester, as the inversion may place pressure on the abdomen and disrupt circulation. People with pre-existing injuries to the back, neck, or shoulders should modify the pose.

name: Plank Pose
precaution: If you have wrist or shoulder injuries, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, tendonitis, or rotator cuff issues, you should approach Plank Pose with caution, as the weight-bearing nature of the pose can aggravate these conditions. If you experience lower back pain, ensure your core is properly engaged and your alignment is correct to avoid sagging in the lower back, which could worsen discomfort. Pregnant individuals, especially in the later stages, should avoid Plank Pose due to the pressure it places on the abdomen and lower back, and instead consider gentler alternatives like a wall plank.

name: Upward-Facing Dog
precaution: Those with lower back issues should be cautious, as overextending the lower back can lead to strain. It’s important to engage the core muscles and lift the chest rather than collapsing in the lower back. Individuals with wrist sensitivity should be mindful of the pressure on the wrists in this pose. For those with shoulder injuries or limited flexibility, it’s crucial to avoid collapsing the shoulders forward. Keep the shoulders away from the ears, draw the shoulder blades down, and ensure the elbows are not locked. Additionally, maintaining proper neck alignment is essential to prevent strain—avoid craning the neck backward too far and keep it in a neutral position. Pregnant individuals, especially in later stages, should avoid this pose due to the pressure it places on the abdomen and lower back. It is also important for those with spinal conditions, such as herniated discs or scoliosis, to consult a healthcare provider before attempting the pose.

name: Child's Pose
precaution: While Child's Pose (Balasana) is generally a gentle and restorative pose, there are some precautions to keep in mind to ensure a safe and effective practice. If you have knee injuries or discomfort, you may want to place a cushion or blanket under your knees for added support and cushioning. For those with lower back pain, it is important to avoid collapsing the lower back or forcing the torso down too far; instead, focus on gently lengthening the spine while keeping the hips aligned over the knees. If you are pregnant, especially in later stages, it's advised to modify the pose by keeping the knees slightly apart to avoid pressure on the belly or chest.

name: Warrior I
precaution: Individuals with knee issues should be cautious when bending the front knee, ensuring it does not extend beyond the ankle to avoid unnecessary pressure on the joint. Those with hip or lower back pain should avoid forcing the hips to square completely forward, as this can cause discomfort or misalignment; instead, they can allow a slight external rotation of the back hip. For practitioners with shoulder injuries or limited mobility, the arms can be kept parallel to the ground or placed on the hips instead of being raised overhead.

name: Warrior II
precaution: If you have knee injuries, especially in the front knee, be cautious about allowing the knee to extend past the ankle, as this can put unnecessary strain on the joint. Those with tight hips or hamstrings should avoid overextending the legs and may need to reduce the depth of the lunge to prevent discomfort or injury. If you have lower back issues, it’s important to be mindful of your hip alignment, ensuring that your hips are open and facing to the side rather than forward, as improper alignment can strain the lower back. Individuals with shoulder problems should avoid lifting the shoulders up toward the ears and focus on relaxing them down to reduce tension. Pregnant individuals or those with balance concerns should modify the pose by shortening their stance or using props for additional support.

name: Warrior III
precaution: Avoid rounding the back and keep the lifted leg in line with the torso. If balancing is difficult, practice near a wall or use a block under the hands for support.

name: Extended Side Angle
precaution: Ensure the knee of the front leg is aligned with the ankle to protect the joint. Avoid collapsing the chest towards the knee and keep the torso open. If you have shoulder pain, avoid the deep shoulder stretch and use a block under the bottom hand.

name: Reverse Warrior
precaution: Avoid over-extending the back and keep the chest open. If you have knee pain, avoid bending the front knee too deeply. Maintain an active core to prevent the lower back from arching.

name: Triangle Pose
precaution: If you have a lower back injury, be careful not to over-stretch and maintain a slight bend in the knees. Avoid collapsing the torso and keep the chest open. Use a block under the bottom hand for added support if needed.

name: Half Moon Pose
precaution: Avoid collapsing the torso forward and keep the spine long. Engage the core for balance and avoid hyperextending the standing leg. Use a block under the lower hand for support if necessary.

name: Chair Pose
precaution: Avoid arching the lower back too much and keep the knees aligned with the toes. Engage the core to protect the spine. If you have knee pain, avoid bending the knees too deeply.

name: Goddess Pose
precaution: Ensure the knees are aligned with the toes and avoid collapsing the chest forward. If you have tight hips, reduce the angle of the knees and keep the feet wider apart.

name: High Lunge
precaution: Keep the front knee aligned with the ankle to avoid strain. If you have knee or hip pain, modify the lunge by keeping the back knee on the ground. Engage the core and avoid arching the lower back.

name: Low Lunge
precaution: Ensure the front knee is directly above the ankle and avoid letting it extend past the toes. If you have knee pain, use a cushion or blanket under the knee for extra support.

name: Pyramid Pose
precaution: If you have hamstring or lower back issues, bend the front knee slightly. Avoid rounding the back excessively and use blocks under the hands for support if necessary.

name: Wide-Legged Forward Fold
precaution: Avoid rounding the back and keep the spine long. If you have hamstring tightness, bend the knees slightly. Use blocks under the hands if necessary to reduce strain on the back.

name: Standing Split
precaution: Avoid locking the knee of the standing leg and keep the hips level. If you have hamstring tightness, bend the standing knee slightly. Use blocks under the hands for additional support if needed.

name: Tree Pose
precaution: Ensure the standing foot is grounded firmly, with the knee pointing outward. Avoid placing the foot on the knee joint, and instead place it on the inner thigh or calf. If you have balance issues, practice near a wall or use a block for support.

name: Dancer's Pose
precaution: If you have knee or hip issues, practice this pose with caution and avoid over-extending. Use a strap around the foot to assist with balance, and keep the chest lifted rather than collapsing the torso.

name: Eagle Pose
precaution: Avoid collapsing the upper body forward. If you have knee or ankle pain, practice this pose with a more supported stance, like placing the foot on the ground instead of wrapping it around the calf.

name: Crow Pose
precaution: Avoid rounding the back excessively, and focus on engaging the core. If you have wrist issues, practice on your forearms. Start by lifting one foot at a time off the ground to build balance.

name: Side Crow
precaution: Ensure the knees are aligned with the elbows and avoid twisting the spine too far. If you're new to this pose, practice the standard Crow Pose first to build strength and balance.

name: Garland Pose
precaution: If you have knee or hip issues, avoid squatting too deeply and use props for additional support. Keep your feet flat on the ground, and avoid forcing your hips down. If you feel any discomfort in your knees or lower back, modify the pose by sitting on a block or cushion. Always listen to your body and avoid pushing beyond your limits.

name: Forearm Stand
precaution: Avoid putting excessive pressure on the neck and wrists. Use a wall for support if you're new to this pose, and engage the core to help lift the legs. If you have shoulder injuries, avoid attempting this pose.

name: Handstand
precaution: Ensure that the wrists are aligned with the shoulders and that you are not arching your back excessively. Practice against a wall for support and avoid this pose if you have wrist, shoulder, or neck issues.

name: Shoulder Stand
precaution: Avoid placing excessive pressure on the neck. Ensure that the weight is supported by the shoulders and upper arms, not the neck. If you have neck or back injuries, avoid this pose or practice with a modified version.

name: Fish Pose
precaution: Avoid overstretching the neck, especially if you have neck pain. Keep the chest lifted and the elbows grounded for support. If you have back or shoulder injuries, avoid going too deep into the pose.

name: Camel Pose
precaution: Avoid over-arching the back and keep the lower ribs drawing in. If you have lower back pain, avoid dropping the head back too far. Use a block under the hands for added support if needed.

name: Bridge Pose
precaution: Engage the core and avoid letting the lower back sag. If you have neck or back issues, keep the head and neck in a neutral position or use a prop for additional support.

name: Wheel Pose
precaution: Avoid straining the lower back. Keep the legs active and the core engaged, and only go as deep as your body allows. If you have shoulder or back injuries, practice with caution and use props for support.

name: Reclining Bound Angle
precaution: Avoid forcing the knees to the ground. If you have tight hips or groin, use props like blocks or cushions under the knees for support. Keep the lower back supported by a cushion or mat if necessary.

name: Legs Up the Wall
precaution: If you have tight hamstrings, keep the legs slightly bent and use a prop like a pillow under the hips for added comfort. Avoid this pose if you have certain circulatory or heart conditions—check with a doctor beforehand.

name: Boat Pose
precaution: Avoid rounding the back and keep the spine long. If you have back pain, perform this pose with your hands behind you for support or keep your feet on the floor instead of lifting them.

name: Seated Forward Fold
precaution: Avoid rounding the back excessively. If you have tight hamstrings, bend the knees slightly to protect the lower back. Use a strap around the feet for a deeper stretch.

name: Bound Angle
precaution: Avoid forcing the knees down to the ground. If you have tight hips or groin, sit on a cushion to lift the hips and reduce strain. Keep the back straight and avoid rounding the spine.

name: Happy Baby Pose
precaution: Keep the feet flexed to protect the knees, and avoid pulling too hard on the feet. If you feel strain in the hips or lower back, use a block or cushion under the hips for support.

name: Corpse Pose
precaution: Ensure the body is fully relaxed, with the body and mind in a neutral state. If you have neck pain, use a cushion or towel under the head for additional support. Stay mindful of your breath to fully relax.

name: Cobra Pose
precaution: If you have lower back pain, keep the elbows slightly bent and avoid pushing too hard into the hands. Engage the legs and core to protect the lower back. Avoid this pose if you have a herniated disc or severe back pain.

name: Locust Pose
precaution: Keep the legs and hips grounded to avoid excessive pressure on the lower back. Engage the core to lift the chest and legs. If you have a back injury, avoid lifting the chest too high or practice with caution.

name: Bow Pose
precaution: Keep the neck in a neutral position to avoid straining it. Engage the core and avoid overextending the back. If you have neck or back issues, practice with caution or skip this pose altogether.

name: Puppy Pose
precaution: If you have tight shoulders or hips, avoid going too deep into the pose. Keep the hips over the knees to avoid strain in the lower back. Use a block under the forehead for added support if needed.

name: Cat-Cow Pose
precaution: If you have neck or back issues, keep the movements slow and controlled. Avoid over-arching the back and dropping the head too far. Keep the core engaged to protect the spine.

name: Thread the Needle
precaution: If you have shoulder issues, perform this pose with caution and keep the shoulder joint stable. Avoid dropping too deep into the twist if you have lower back pain.

name: Reverse Plank Pose
precaution: If you have wrist issues, avoid putting excessive pressure on your wrists by using a rolled towel or yoga wedge under your hands for support. Engage your core to prevent strain on the lower back, and avoid dropping your head back if it causes discomfort in the neck. Ensure proper alignment and listen to your body to avoid overstretching or straining the shoulders.

name: Pigeon Pose
precaution: If you have knee, hip, or lower back injuries, practice with caution. Use props like blocks or a bolster under the hips for support, and keep the chest lifted to avoid collapsing the spine.

name: Plow Pose
precaution: If you have neck or spine issues, avoid letting your head drop back too far and ensure your neck is supported. Keep a slight bend in your knees if you feel discomfort in the hamstrings or lower back. If you're new to this pose, use a blanket or cushion under your back for additional support. Always move into and out of the pose with control to avoid straining the neck or shoulders.

name: Supine Twist
precaution: If you have a back injury, perform this twist gently and avoid forcing the body deeper into the stretch. Use a cushion under the knees if you feel strain in the lower back.

name: Half Lord of the Fishes
precaution: Avoid twisting too deeply if you have lower back or neck pain. Keep the spine long and engage the core for support. Use props like a block to support the hip if needed.

name: Side Plank
precaution: Avoid collapsing the shoulder joint and ensure the wrist is directly beneath the shoulder. If you have wrist, shoulder, or core issues, practice this pose with caution or use modifications like knee support.

name: Wild Thing
precaution: Keep the shoulder joints stable and avoid overextending the back. If you have neck or back issues, practice with caution and use a block under the foot for support.

name: Tiger Pose
precaution: Avoid over-arching the back and keep the core engaged. If you have knee or back issues, perform this pose gently and with proper alignment.

name: Gate Pose
precaution: Avoid over-stretching the inner thigh and keep the hips squared. If you have knee or hip issues, perform this pose gently and avoid pushing too far into the stretch.

name: Frog Pose
precaution: If you have knee or hip issues, practice with caution and avoid forcing the knees to the floor. Use props like blankets or cushions under the knees for support.

name: Lizard Pose
precaution: If you have tight hips or knees, use props under the hips for support. Keep the back leg active to protect the knee and avoid letting the knee collapse inward.

name: Fallen Triangle
precaution: If you have neck, shoulder, or back issues, perform this pose gently and avoid going too deep into the stretch. Keep the legs strong and the hips lifted for support.

name: Bird of Paradise
precaution: If you have balance issues, practice near a wall or use a block for support. Avoid forcing the leg into a bind, and only go as far as feels comfortable in the twist.

name: Extended Hand-to-Big-Toe Pose
precaution: If you have hamstring or lower back tightness, bend the standing leg slightly. Keep the spine long and avoid rounding the back to protect the lower back.

name: Standing Forward Fold
precaution: If you have tight hamstrings or lower back pain, bend the knees slightly to avoid straining the lower back. Keep the core engaged and avoid rounding the back.

name: Halfway Lift
precaution: Keep the spine long and avoid rounding the back. If you have lower back or neck issues, perform the lift gently, and avoid overextending the chest.

name: Ragdoll Pose
precaution: If you have neck issues, keep the head relaxed and avoid pulling on the neck. Bend the knees slightly if you have tight hamstrings or back pain.

name: Eight-Angle Pose
precaution: This pose requires balance and core strength. If you have wrist or shoulder issues, practice with caution or skip this pose.

name: Bound Side Angle
precaution: Avoid over-extending the lower back or neck. Keep the knee above the ankle and ensure the hips are squared to protect the joints.

name: Bound Forward Fold
precaution: Avoid forcing the body into the fold. Keep the knees slightly bent if you have tight hamstrings or back pain.

name: Half Splits
precaution: Keep the hips squared and avoid forcing the fold. If you have knee or hamstring issues, use props for support and don’t over-extend.

name: Full Splits
precaution: If you have tight hips or hamstrings, practice with caution. Use props like blocks under the hips for support and avoid forcing the legs into a full split.

name: King Pigeon Pose
precaution: If you have knee, hip, or back injuries, avoid deepening the stretch. Use props to support the hips or head, and maintain a long spine.

name: Lotus Pose
precaution: If you have knee, hip, or ankle issues, avoid this pose. Sit on a cushion to lift the hips and keep the spine straight. Do not force the legs into position.

name: Elevated Lotus Pose
precaution: Avoid practicing this pose if you have wrist, shoulder, or knee injuries. Ensure the wrists are properly aligned and do not overstrain. Engage the core to prevent collapsing into the shoulders, and use a prop or modify the pose if lifting the body feels too intense.

name: Cow Face Pose
precaution: If you have shoulder or knee issues, avoid forcing the legs into position. Keep the spine long and use props if needed to support the knees.

name: Seated Spinal Twist
precaution: Twist gently to avoid straining the lower back. Keep the spine long and avoid over-rotating if you have neck or back issues.

name: Hero Pose
precaution: If you have knee or ankle issues, use a cushion or block under the hips for support. Keep the spine long and avoid collapsing the chest.

name: Revolved Triangle
precaution: Keep the hips squared and avoid over-twisting. If you have neck or back injuries, practice with caution and keep the twist gentle.

name: Revolved Side Angle
precaution: If you have knee, back, or neck injuries, avoid over-rotating. Use a block under the hand if you feel any strain in the lower back.

name: Shoulder Pressing Pose
precaution: Avoid straining the wrists or shoulders. If you have wrist or shoulder injuries, practice this pose with caution and keep the core engaged for stability.

name: Flying Pigeon Pose
precaution: This pose requires balance and flexibility. If you have wrist, shoulder, or hip issues, practice with caution and use props for stability.

name: Firefly Pose
precaution: Keep the wrists strong and avoid collapsing the shoulders. If you have lower back or hip injuries, practice with caution and use blocks for support.

name: Monkey Pose
precaution: If you have tight hamstrings or lower back pain, bend the knee slightly and avoid over-extending the spine. Use props to support the fold if needed.

name: Ganda Bherundasana (Chin Stand)
precaution: This pose requires significant balance and shoulder strength. Avoid if you have neck, back, or shoulder injuries. Practice under supervision, especially when learning.

name: Scorpion Pose (Vrschikasana)
precaution: Avoid this pose if you have neck or back issues. Practice this pose gently and ensure strong core engagement to protect the lower back and neck.

name: Half Moon Bound Pose (Baddha Ardha Chandrasana)
precaution: Be cautious if you have knee, hip, or shoulder injuries. Keep the hips squared and avoid over-stretching. Use a block under the hand for additional support.

name: Hummingbird Pose (Mayurasana)
precaution: This pose requires significant wrist and core strength. If you have wrist, shoulder, or lower back issues, practice with caution or avoid it entirely.

name: Peacock Pose (Mayurasana)
precaution: Requires core strength and balance. Avoid if you have wrist, shoulder, or abdominal issues. Engage the core deeply and keep the back flat.

name: Compass Pose (Parivrtta Surya Yantrasana)
precaution: If you have tight hips, lower back pain, or shoulder injuries, practice with caution. Keep the core engaged and avoid forcing the twist.

name: Sleeping Vishnu (Anantasana)
precaution: If you have shoulder or hip issues, use props to support the body. Keep the spine long and avoid collapsing the chest.

name: Dragonfly Pose (Maksikanagasana)
precaution: This pose requires flexibility and balance. If you have wrist, shoulder, or hip injuries, practice with caution and avoid forcing the body into position.

name: Grasshopper Pose (Maksikanagasana Variation)
precaution: Practice with caution if you have wrist, shoulder, or hip issues. Focus on building strength and flexibility gradually.

name: Baby Grasshopper (Parsva Bhuja Dandasana)
precaution: This pose involves balance and strength in the wrists, shoulders, and core. Avoid if you have wrist or shoulder injuries.

name: Caterpillar Pose (Paschimottanasana Variation)
precaution: If you have tight hamstrings or lower back pain, bend the knees slightly to avoid straining. Keep the spine long and avoid rounding the back.

name: Revolved Chair Pose (Parivrtta Utkatasana)
precaution: Avoid if you have knee, back, or shoulder injuries. Keep the knees aligned and avoid over-rotating the spine.

name: Side Stretch Pose (Parsvottanasana)
precaution: If you have tight hamstrings or lower back pain, bend the knees slightly. Avoid rounding the back and keep the core engaged.

name: Hero Pose with Recline (Supta Virasana)
precaution: Avoid if you have knee, hip, or lower back issues. Use props under the hips and knees for support if needed.

name: Intense Side Stretch (Parsvottanasana)
precaution: If you have tight hamstrings or lower back pain, bend the knees slightly. Keep the spine long and avoid rounding the back.

name: Revolved Crescent Lunge (Parivrtta Alanasana)
precaution: Avoid over-rotating the spine if you have back or neck issues. Keep the front knee aligned and avoid pushing the body too deep into the twist.

name: Tortoise Pose (Kurmasana)
precaution: If you have tight hips or hamstrings, practice with caution. Avoid collapsing the chest, and keep the spine long.

name: One-Legged Bridge Pose (Setu Bandha Sarvangasana with one leg lifted)
precaution: Be cautious if you have lower back or hip issues. Keep the core engaged and avoid arching the back excessively.

name: Wheel Pose Variation (Urdhva Dhanurasana with one leg lifted)
precaution: If you have back, shoulder, or hip issues, avoid this variation. Focus on lifting from the chest and avoid overextending the back.

name: Standing Bow Pose (Dandayamana Dhanurasana)
precaution: Avoid over-arching the lower back. If you have back, hip, or knee issues, practice with caution and keep the torso aligned.
